raw_text:
Tate & Lyle boss bags top award
 
 Tate & Lyle's chief executive has been named European Businessman of the Year by a leading business magazine.
 
 Iain Ferguson was awarded the title by US publication Forbes for returning one of the UK's "venerable" manufacturers to the country's top 100 companies. The sugar group had been absent from the FTSE 100 for seven years until Mr Ferguson helped it return to growth. Tate's shares have leapt 55% this year, boosted by firming sugar prices and sales of its artificial sweeteners.
 
 "After years of a sagging stock price and a seven-year hiatus from the FTSE 100, one of Britain's venerable manufacturers has returned to the vaunted index," Forbes said. Mr Ferguson took the helm at the company in 2003, after spending most of his career at consumer goods giant Unilever. Tate & Lyle, which was an original member of the historic FT-30 index in 1935, operates more than 41 factories and 20 more additional production facilities in 28 countries. Previous winners of the Forbes award include Royal Bank of Scotland chief executive Fred Goodwin and former Vodafone boss Chris Gent.
llama3.2:1b: Tate & Lyle's chief executive Iain Ferguson has been named European Businessman of the Year by US publication Forbes after helping the company return to the FTSE 100 list.
llama3.2:3b: Tate & Lyle's CEO Iain Ferguson was named European Businessman of the Year by Forbes for returning the company to the FTSE 100 after a seven-year absence. Tate's shares have increased 55% this year, driven by sugar price increases and artificial sweetener sales. Mr. Ferguson took over in 2003 and led the company back to growth.
gemma2:2b: Iain Ferguson, CEO of Tate & Lyle, has been awarded European Businessman of the Year by Forbes for returning the company to the UK's top 100 companies. His leadership has led to a 55% increase in Tate's share price and contributed to the company's resurgence following seven years off the FTSE 100.

Shares have risen 55% this year due to improved sugar prices and sales of artificial sweeteners. Ferguson took over in 2003 after a career at Unilever; Tate & Lyle joined the historic FT-30 index in 1935 and operates factories in 28 countries. Previous winners include Fred Goodwin and Chris Gent.

The company returns to the FTSE 100 for seven years until Mr Ferguson helps it return to growth. Forbes said in an article. The historic sugar group has been absent from the FTSE 100 for seven years.
smollm:1.7b: The summary should be: Tate & Lyle boss bags top award
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text. Let me read through it carefully.

The first sentence mentions that Tate & Lyle's CEO was named the European Businessman of the Year by a business magazine. That's good news for them because it makes their company stand out internationally.

Then there's another part about Forbes publication. They awarded Iain Ferguson, who was previously at Unilever and helped bring the sugar group back to the FTSE 100 after seven years missing that index. This is important because the FTSE 100 is a big ranking list for UK stocks, so this win would showcase their performance.

I should focus on the key points: the CEO's recognition, the award recipient Mr. Ferguson, the company's return to growth with more factories and production, the reasons for his return (Unilever experience), and how it benefits Tate & Lyle by boosting sugar prices and artificial sweeteners. Also, I should note that the FTSE 100 was a seven-year gap before he joined, which is significant.

I need to keep only the main ideas without extra details. So, starting with Tate & Lyle being named European Businessman of the Year, then Mr. Ferguson's award details, his role at Unilever, how he helped return the sugar group, their stock performance, and the impact on their operations. That should cover everything succinctly.
</think>

Tate & Lyle's CEO was awarded the European Businessman of the Year by a business magazine, recognizing Iain Ferguson. Mr. Ferguson, who returned his company to the FTSE 100 after seven years missing it at Unilever, helped bring the sugar group back and saw its stock rise 55%. Tate & Lyle has 41 factories and is operating in over 28 countries.
tinyllama:1.1b: Tate & Lyle's CEO Iain Ferguson has been named European Businessman of the Year by a leading business magazine, earning him a top spot on their annual FTSE 100 list. The sugar manufacturer had been absent from the index for over seven years until Mr Ferguson helped it return to growth in recent years, following a slump that lasted for nearly a decade. Tate & Lyle's stock price has leapt by over 55% this year, thanks in part to stronger sugar prices and sales of its artificial sweeteners. The company operates more than 41 factories and 20 more production facilities globally, with Mr Ferguson at the helm for more than a decade now. Previous winners of the award include Royal Bank of Scotland CEO Fred Goodwin and former VoDAfonE boss Chris Gent.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Tate & Lyle has been honored with the prestigious Forbes European Businessman of the Year award, recognizing their successful turnaround and return to the top tier of UK stocks after a seven-year absence. The company's success can be attributed to Iain Ferguson, who played an instrumental role in rekindling Tate & Lyle's position within the FTSE 100 index. His tenure as CEO has seen Tate & Lyle experiencing growth and success through various initiatives such as increasing sugar prices and expanding its artificial sweeteners offerings. As a result, the company's shares have skyrocketed, garnering widespread attention and admiration from both industry insiders and investors alike.
